docs.abstract: Little representatives of a dying world.
docs.snippet: Little representatives of a dying world.
docs.lead_paragraph: Each day, against the blank expanse of Arabian desert just outside my office window, a procession of wild animals continues its relentlessly static march to nowhere. The heart of it comprises a sprawling array of apes — four chimps, a band of mountain gorillas, one orangutan — each of them caught midstride, -strike or -thought. Nearby, a herd of elephants treads noiselessly, trunks and ears flailing, like a pod of land-whales adrift above a dry, ancient seabed. Following behind, a pride of jungle cats — tigers, lions, a cheetah cub, a jaguar, an ocelot — pads about the slow, mine-sweeping snouts of a passing crash of rhinos. Far up ahead, a hyacinth macaw takes flight above two meerkats, standing their endless vigil.

docs.abstract: A childhood betrayal complicated by cultural dynamics and learned behavior.
docs.snippet: A childhood betrayal complicated by cultural dynamics and learned behavior.
docs.lead_paragraph: Childhood betrayals: We’ve all experienced them, then more or less tucked them away. Merely reading the list of affinities shared by the two preschool B.F.F.s in Ines Rivera’s poem seems a portent of their inevitable falling out. But this unnerving incident is no ordinary treachery; it’s complicated by cultural dynamics and learned behavior induced by perceptions of, or attitudes toward, gender and race — concepts that are often confusing to children, who tend to take their lead from their elders. And thus fear breeds distrust and spirals into manufactured hate, until another song of innocence skids to a shuddering stop. Selected by Rita Dove

byline.original: By Ines P. Rivera Prosdocimi and Rita Dove

docs.abstract: The Lyft president on self-driving cars, climate change and not reinventing the bus.
docs.snippet: The Lyft president on self-driving cars, climate change and not reinventing the bus.
docs.lead_paragraph: When ride-sharing apps made their debut a few years ago, lots of people thought it was crazy to get in a stranger’s car, and now we all do it at 2 a.m. without even thinking. Did you expect attitudes to change so quickly? It definitely moved faster than, I think, anyone — including myself — thought. We knew that we would need to change people’s behavior. It actually was one of the main reasons the original tagline was “your friend with a car.”

headline.main: John Zimmer Would Rather Die Than Take an Uber
headline.print_headline: John Zimmer Would Rather Die Than Take An Uber

docs.abstract: It’s more than just a memoir: It’s logistically stupefying, touching and absolutely packed with choice late-’80s gossip.
docs.snippet: It’s more than just a memoir: It’s logistically stupefying, touching and absolutely packed with choice late-’80s gossip.
docs.lead_paragraph: Drew Barrymore had her first cigarette when she was 9. Within three years, she would drink her first beer, smoke her first bowl and do her first bump of coke. Soon she was regularly going to a nightclub in Silverlake, a spot favored by Jack Nicholson and Madonna and run by a family friend. Barrymore and her young pals had a routine: They would go up to the balcony, rip cigs and keep watch for drinks to swipe down below. “A few times we passed out up there, slept for several hours and woke up with monumental headaches,” Barrymore would later write, “a combination of the alcohol and lying with our ears right beside the speakers.” It was 1990 when she published those words, and she was 14, having already lived long and hard enough to write a rehab memoir, “Little Girl Lost.”

headline.main: Letter of Recommendation: Drew Barrymore’s ‘Little Girl Lost’

docs.abstract: Caramelized-scallion sauce isn’t pretty, but it tastes fantastic on everything it touches.
docs.snippet: Caramelized-scallion sauce isn’t pretty, but it tastes fantastic on everything it touches.
docs.lead_paragraph: I went viral once. With each tweet, share and like, my brainchild rocketed further and further across the internet. It was giddy-making. I sat up a little taller in my office cubicle. I felt electric, and I found myself wondering — no fantasizing — “What if I ... become ... an influencer?”

headline.main: Caramelized-Scallion Sauce Will Never Go Viral (But It Should)
headline.print_headline: Some Recipes Will Never Go Viral (But They Should)
